page.title: 02LANDSCAPE OF NEWTON BLOCK.
page.content: The oolitic limestone rises here from the wide coastal plain and is drained by streams which rise at springs where clay is exposed at a limestone edge. The land folds gently,rising from under 20m in E to more than 60m in W. Few buildings can be seen as villages and farms are tucked into folds and dips and are well-screened by trees. The fields are large and mainly arable though adjacent to villages there is often grassland.In parts the aspect is prairie-like but around Newton village hedges do mark the individual fields and woodland and coppices lie amid the arable land.The broach spire of Aunsby church can be seen from many places and from the highest point Boston Stump which is 17 miles away.
